questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents with symptoms suggestive of a metabolic disorder. Biochemical tests are performed to analyze protein structures and their carbohydrate components. The medical team needs to differentiate between glycoproteins and proteoglycans to better understand the patient’s condition. Which of the following statements is correct?

options.label: B
options.text: Proteoglycans have long mucopolysaccharide chains and high carbohydrate content.

options.label: C
options.text: Glycoproteins have long mucopolysaccharide chains and higher carbohydrate content

options.label: D
options.text: Proteoglycans contain short oligosaccharide chains and lower carbohydrate content

questions.correct_answer: B. Proteoglycans have long mucopolysaccharide chains and high carbohydrate content.
questions.explanation:
Property

Glycoproteins

Proteoglycans

Carbohydrates content

Low

High

Basic difference

Oligosaccharide chain

Mucopolysaccharide chain

Charge

Not negatively charged
  • Negatively charged
  • sulfated or acetylated

Location
  • Plasma proteins
  • Cellular receptors – except albumin
  • Receptors made up of simple proteins can not be heterogenous, as simple proteins are made up of just 2- aminoacids which can be linked by peptide linkages. Lack of heterogeneity causes lack of specificity
  • ECM - extracellular matrix

questions.text: Which sequence correctly represents the steps of the oxidative phase of the pentose phosphate pathway (PPP)?
questions.explanation:
Step

Substrates

Enzyme

Products

1

Glucose-6-phosphate + NADP+

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase

6-Phosphogluconolactone + NADPH

2

6-Phosphogluconolactone

Gluconolactone hydrolase

6-Phosphogluconate

3

6-Phosphogluconate + NADP+

6-Phosphogluconate dehydrogenase

Ribulose-5-phosphate + NADPH + CO2

questions.text: A child is diagnosed with essential fructosuria during a routine health check. Name the enzyme A responsible for this condition
questions.explanation:
Dietary Source

Found in fruits, honey, and high-fructose corn syrup

Structure

Ketohexose

Metabolism Site

Primarily metabolized by the liver

Fructose Metabolism :

1) Phosphorylation:

  • Fructokinase is the primary enzyme for fructose phosphorylation. It has a high affinity (low Km) and a high Vmax for fructose. It converts fructose to fructose-1-phosphate using ATP. It is found in the liver, kidneys, and small intestine.

 

2) Fructose 1-Phosphate Cleavage:

  • Aldolase B cleaves fructose 1-phosphate to dihydroxyacetone phosphate (DHAP) and glyceraldehyde. It is present in the liver, kidneys, and small intestine. 
  • DHAP enters glycolysis or gluconeogenesis.
  • Glyceraldehyde is metabolized through various pathways.

Disorders of Fructose Metabolism

1) Essential Fructosuria:

  • Benign metabolic disorder
  • Caused by fructokinase deficiency
  • Excretion of fructose in urine
  • Low risk of cataracts as aldose reductase does not act on fructose, and sorbitol dehydrogenase has low affinity for it.

2) Hereditary Fructose Intolerance (HFI):

  • Caused by aldolase B deficiency. (Option A ruled out)
  • Symptoms appear when infants consume sucrose or fructose.
  • Effects are due to accumulation of fructose 1-phosphate.
  • Symptoms: Vomiting, appetite loss, failure to thrive, hepatomegaly, jaundice, potential liver damage and death
  • Diagnosis: Detection of fructose in urine, enzyme assay using liver cells or DNA-based testing.
  • Treatment: Remove sucrose, sorbitol and fructose from the diet.

questions.text: Which of the following factors regulates the expression of PEPCK in liver cells?
questions.explanation:
Regulator Effect on PEPCK Mechanism
Glucagon Increases ↑ cAMP → ↑ PKA → ↑ PEPCK transcription
Insulin Decreases ↓ cAMP → ↓ PKA → ↓ PEPCK transcription
Cortisol Increases Activates PEPCK gene transcription
Glucose Decreases Inhibits gluconeogenic enzymes
Acetyl-CoA Activates pyruvate carboxylase Does not directly regulate PEPCK

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes in gluconeogenesis is considered a "tandem enzyme" with fructose-2,6-bisphosphatase, functioning in the opposite direction?
questions.explanation:
Tandem Enzyme Pair Glycolysis Enzyme Gluconeogenesis Enzyme Function & Regulation
PFK-2 / FBPase-2 Phosphofructokinase-2 (PFK-2) Fructose-2,6-bisphosphatase (FBPase-2) Regulates fructose-2,6-bisphosphate levels, controlling glycolysis & gluconeogenesis.
Hexokinase / Glucose-6-phosphatase Hexokinase/Glucokinase Glucose-6-phosphatase Controls phosphorylation and dephosphorylation of glucose.
Pyruvate kinase / PEPCK Pyruvate kinase Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase (PEPCK) Controls conversion between PEP and pyruvate, linking glycolysis and gluconeogenesis.
Condition PFK-2 Activity FBPase-2 Activity Metabolic Effect
Fed state (Insulin ↑) Active Inhibited ↑ Fructose-2,6-bisphosphate → ↑ Glycolysis
Fasting state (Glucagon ↑, cAMP ↑, PKA ↑) Inhibited Active ↓ Fructose-2,6-bisphosphate → ↑ Gluconeogenesis

Regulatory Factor

Effect on PFK-2/FBPase-2

Metabolic Outcome

Insulin (Fed State)

Activates PFK-2

↑ Glycolysis, ↓ Gluconeogenesis

Glucagon (Fasting State)

Activates FBPase-2

↓ Glycolysis, ↑ Gluconeogenesis

Fructose-2,6-bisphosphate

Stimulates PFK-1, inhibits FBPase-1

↑ Glycolysis, ↓ Gluconeogenesis

cAMP / PKA Activation

Phosphorylates enzyme → Activates FBPase-2

Promotes gluconeogenesis

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes involved in gluconeogenesis is located in the endoplasmic reticulum?
questions.explanation:
Enzyme Location Function Cofactors
Pyruvate Carboxylase (Option A ruled out) Mitochondria Converts pyruvate to oxaloacetate Biotin, ATP, CO₂
Phosphoenolpyruvate Carboxykinase (PEPCK) (Option B ruled out) Cytoplasm & Mitochondria Converts oxaloacetate to PEP GTP (as a phosphate donor)
Fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase (Option C ruled out) Cytoplasm Converts F-1,6-BP to F-6-P Mg²⁺
Glucose-6-phosphatase Endoplasmic Reticulum Converts G-6-P to free glucose Mg²

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the amphibolic nature of the citric acid cycle?

options.label: A
options.text: It generates ATP and produces citrate for fatty acid synthesis.

options.label: B
options.text: It exclusively produces NADH for oxidative phosphorylation.

options.label: C
options.text: It breaks down fatty acids and synthesises only cholesterol.

options.label: D
options.text: It provides intermediates solely for glucose synthesis.

questions.correct_answer: A. It generates ATP and produces citrate for fatty acid synthesis.

questions.text: Calculate the total amount of ATP produced from the Citric Acid Cycle alone for one glucose molecule.
questions.explanation:
Molecule Produced ATP Yield per Molecule Total ATP for 2 Cycles
NADH (3 per cycle) 2.5 ATP 3 × 2.5 × 2 = 15 ATP
FADH₂ (1 per cycle) 1.5 ATP 1 × 1.5 × 2 = 3 ATP
GTP (Direct ATP) (1 per cycle) 1 ATP 1 × 2 = 2 ATP
Total ATP   20 ATP
Feature Details
Location Mitochondrial matrix
Purpose Oxidation of Acetyl-CoA to generate ATP, NADH, and FADH₂
Entry Molecule Acetyl-CoA (from glycolysis, fatty acid oxidation, or amino acid metabolism)
End Products per Cycle 3 NADH (Produces 7.5 ATP)
1 FADH₂ (Produces 1.5 ATP)
1 ATP (GTP)
2 CO₂ (Byproduct)
ATP Yield per Glucose 20 ATP (from 2 Acetyl-CoA)
Regulatory Enzymes Citrate Synthase (Inhibited by ATP, NADH, and Succinyl-CoA)
Isocitrate Dehydrogenase (Rate-limiting step, inhibited by ATP and NADH)
α-Ketoglutarate Dehydrogenase (Inhibited by ATP, NADH, and Succinyl-CoA)
Significance Provides intermediates for biosynthesis (e.g., amino acids, heme, fatty acids)
Generates reducing equivalents (NADH, FADH₂) for the electron transport chain
Integrates carbohydrate, lipid, and protein metabolism
Step Reaction Enzyme ATP/NADH/FADH₂ Produced
1 Acetyl-CoA + Oxaloacetate → Citrate Citrate Synthase -
2 Citrate → Isocitrate Aconitase -
3 Isocitrate → α-Ketoglutarate + CO₂ Isocitrate Dehydrogenase 1 NADH (2.5 ATP)
4 α-Ketoglutarate → Succinyl-CoA + CO₂ α-Ketoglutarate Dehydrogenase 1 NADH (2.5 ATP)
5 Succinyl-CoA → Succinate Succinyl-CoA Synthetase 1 ATP (GTP)
6 Succinate → Fumarate Succinate Dehydrogenase 1 FADH₂ (1.5 ATP)
7 Fumarate → Malate Fumarase -
8 Malate → Oxaloacetate Malate Dehydrogenase 1 NADH (2.5 ATP)

Regulator Effect on TCA Cycle Mechanism
ATP Inhibits High energy status
NADH Inhibits High reducing equivalents
ADP Activates Low energy status
Ca²⁺ Activates Stimulates muscle contraction and energy demand

questions.text: Which of the following by-products from the Krebs Cycle is involved in heme synthesis?
All of the following metabolic pathways occur in the cytoplasm except?
questions.explanation:
Cytoplasm

Mitochondria
  • Glycolysis (Option A ruled out)
  • Pentose Phosphate Pathway (Option B ruled out)
  • Fatty Acid Synthesis (Option C ruled out)
  • Urea Cycle (partial- Cytoplasm & Mitochondria)
  • HMP Shunt
  • Krebs Cycle (Citric Acid Cycle)
  • Electron Transport Chain
  • Fatty Acid Oxidation
  • Ketogenesis
Gluconeogenesis occurs in the cytoplasm, mitochondria, and endoplasmic reticulum.

questions.text: Identify the type of linkage in the given Structure.
questions.explanation:
O-linked glycoproteins

(post-translation modification)
  • Carbohydrate chains are attached to the oxygen atom of serine or threonine residues.
  • Mucins: Major components of mucus, providing lubrication and protection to epithelial surfaces.
  • Glycoproteins in collagen

N-linked glycoproteins

(Option B)
  • Carbohydrate chains are attached to the nitrogen atom of asparagine residues.
  • Immunoglobulins (IgG) & Erythropoietin

GPI anchored Glycoproteins

(Option C)
  • Carbohydrates are not attached to any amino acid
  • Anchor consists of a lipid tail (phosphatidylinositol) and a glycan chain, which covalently links the protein to the membrane.

questions.text: Assertion (A): Glycogen and amylopectin are both branched polysaccharides composed of glucose units. Reason (R): The branch points in glycogen occur every 8-12 glucose residues, while in amylopectin, they occur every 20-30 glucose residues.

options.label: A
options.text: Both the assertion and the reason are correct, and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion.

options.label: B
options.text: Both the assertion and the reason are correct, but the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion.

options.label: C
options.text: The assertion is correct, but the reason is incorrect.

options.label: D
options.text: The assertion is incorrect, but the reason is correct.

questions.correct_answer: A. Both the assertion and the reason are correct, and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion.
questions.explanation:
Feature

Amylopectin

Glycogen

Source

Plants

Animals

Structure

 Moderately branched, larger molecules Highly branched, compact molecules.

Branching

Less frequent (every 20-30 glucose units)

More frequent (every 8-12 glucose units)

Glucose Linkages

 α-1,4 and α-1,6 glycosidic bonds α-1,4 and α-1,6 glycosidic bonds

Solubility

Less soluble

More soluble

Granule Shape

Larger, spherical

Smaller, irregular

Hydrolysis Enzyme

Amylase and limit dextrinase

Glycogen phosphorylase and debranching enzyme

Function

Energy storage in plants

 Rapid energy mobilization in animals

questions.explanation:
Mucopolysaccharide (MPS)

Components

Keratan Sulfate

Galactose and N-acetylglucosamine

Glucuronic acid (or iduronic acid) and N-sulfated glucosamine

Dermatan Sulfate (Option D)

Iduronic acid and N-acetylgalactosamine

Chondroitin Sulfate (Option C)

Glucuronic acid and N-acetylgalactosamine

Hyaluronic Acid

Glucuronic acid and N-acetylglucosamine

questions.text: Which category of carbohydrates consists of molecules that cannot be hydrolyzed into simpler sugars?
questions.explanation:
Type

Feature

Monosaccharides

Single carbohydrate unit in them

Ex: glucose, fructose

Disaccharides

Two monosaccharide units

Ex: sucrose, maltose, isomaltose, trehalose, lactose

Oligosaccharides

3- 10 monosaccharide units

Ex: Maltotriose

Polysaccharides

More than 10 monosaccharide units

Ex: starch, cellulose, glycogen

questions.text: Which glycogen storage disease does not involve hypoglycemia or exercise intolerance?
questions.explanation:
Aspect Details
Enzyme Deficiency Branching enzyme (glycogen branching enzyme)
Affected Gene GBE1
Mode of Inheritance Autosomal recessive
Key Features Hepatosplenomegaly, cirrhosis, failure to thrive
Hypoglycemia Absent (Unlike Von Gierke or Cori disease)
Exercise Intolerance Absent (Unlike McArdle or Tarui disease)
Prognosis Progressive liver disease, leading to liver failure

GSD Type Name Enzyme Deficiency Affected Gene Key Features Hypoglycemia Exercise Intolerance
GSD I Von Gierke Disease (Option A ruled out) Glucose-6-phosphatase G6PC Severe hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, lactic acidosis, hyperuricemia, hyperlipidemia Yes No
GSD II Pompe Disease Lysosomal acid maltase (α1,4-glucosidase) GAA Cardiomegaly, muscle hypotonia, early death (infantile form) No Yes
GSD III Cori Disease (Forbes Disease) Debranching enzyme AGL Mild hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, muscle weakness, limit dextrin accumulation Yes Yes
GSD IV Andersen Disease Branching enzyme GBE1 Hepatosplenomegaly, cirrhosis, no hypoglycemia or exercise intolerance No No
GSD V McArdle Disease (Option B ruled out) Muscle glycogen phosphorylase PYGM Exercise intolerance, muscle cramps, myoglobinuria No Yes
GSD VI Hers Disease Liver glycogen phosphorylase PYGL Mild hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly Yes No
GSD VII Tarui Disease (Option D ruled out) Muscle phosphofructokinase-1 PFKM Exercise intolerance, hemolysis No Yes
GSD IX Phosphorylase kinase deficiency Phosphorylase kinase PHKA1, PHKB, PHKG2 Hepatomegaly, mild hypoglycemia, muscle weakness (some subtypes) Yes Yes
GSD XI Fanconi-Bickel Syndrome GLUT2 transporter defect SLC2A2 Hepatorenal dysfunction, growth retardation, glucose/galactose intolerance Yes No
GSD 0 Glycogen Synthase Deficiency Glycogen synthase GYS1, GYS2 Ketotic hypoglycemia, postprandial hyperglycemia, no glycogen storage Yes No

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with recurrent episodes of hypoglycemia and elevated ketone levels. Genetic testing was done and diagnosed as Type 0 Glycogen storage disorder. Which of the following statements about Glycogen Storage Disease Type 0 is true?

options.label: A
options.text: The enzyme deficiency is glycogen synthase.

options.label: B
options.text: The affected genes are GYS2 and GYS1.

options.label: C
options.text: It is an autosomal recessive disorder

questions.explanation:
Feature Details
Cause Glycogen synthase deficiency (caused by GYS1 or GYS2 mutation)- an autosomal recessive disorder. (Options A, B & C)
Pathophysiology Inability to synthesize glycogen → Reduced glycogen stores → Fasting hypoglycemia and ketosis
Clinical Features Fasting hypoglycemia, ketosis, postprandial hyperglycemia, muscle weakness (GYS1 mutation)
Diagnosis Genetic testing (GYS1, GYS2 mutation), blood glucose and ketone levels
Management Frequent meals, cornstarch supplementation, avoiding fasting

questions.text: A 1 year old child presents with failure to thrive, weak bones, and renal dysfunction. The physician suspected glycogen storage disorder and further identified a mutation in the SLC2A2 gene while genetic testing. Which among the following defects is associated with it?
questions.explanation:
Feature Details
Cause Mutation in SLC2A2 gene leading to defective GLUT2 transporter
Affected Organs Liver, kidney, intestines, pancreas
Pathophysiology Impaired glucose transport → Hepatic glycogen accumulation → Renal Fanconi syndrome
Clinical Features Failure to thrive, hepatomegaly, renal dysfunction, osteopenia, hypophosphatemic rickets, fasting hypoglycemia
Diagnosis Genetic testing (SLC2A2 mutation), urine analysis (glycosuria, phosphaturia, aminoaciduria), fasting blood glucose
Management Supportive care, frequent small meals, vitamin D and phosphate supplementation, uncooked cornstarch to prevent fasting hypoglycemia

questions.text: Match the glycogen storage disorders with their respective enzyme defects. Glycogen Storage Disorders: Enzyme Defects: 1. Pompe Disease a. Debranching enzyme 2. McArdle Disease b. Acid maltase 3. Von Gierke Disease c. Glucose-6-phosphatase 4. Cori Disease d. Myophosphorylase
questions.explanation:
Glycogen Storage Disorder Enzyme Defect Pathophysiology
Pompe Disease (Type II) Acid maltase (Lysosomal α-1,4-glucosidase) Accumulation of glycogen in lysosomes due to defective degradation
McArdle Disease (Type V) Myophosphorylase (Muscle glycogen phosphorylase) Impaired glycogen breakdown in muscle, causing exercise intolerance
Von Gierke Disease (Type I) Glucose-6-phosphatase Defective glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis, leading to severe hypoglycemia
Cori Disease (Type III) Debranching enzyme (α-1,6-glucosidase) Abnormal glycogen with short outer chains, leading to mild hypoglycemia and hepatomegaly

GSD Type Name Enzyme Defect Affected Organs Key Features
Type I Von Gierke Disease Glucose-6-phosphatase Liver, Kidney Severe fasting hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, lactic acidosis
Type II Pompe Disease Acid maltase (Lysosomal α-1,4-glucosidase) Muscle, Heart Cardiomegaly, hypotonia, early death in infantile form
Type III Cori Disease Debranching enzyme (α-1,6-glucosidase) Liver, Muscle Mild hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, muscle weakness
Type V McArdle Disease Myophosphorylase (Muscle glycogen phosphorylase) Skeletal Muscle Exercise intolerance, muscle cramps, myoglobinuria

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly differentiates liver glycogen phosphorylase (LGP) and muscle glycogen phosphorylase (MGP)?

options.label: A
options.text: LGP is activated by glucagon, while MGP is activated by epinephrine.

options.label: B
options.text: LGP releases glucose-6-phosphate into the bloodstream, while MGP releases free glucose into the muscle.

options.label: C
options.text: LGP activity is regulated by AMP, while MGP is regulated by glucagon and epinephrine.

options.label: D
options.text: MGP is highly active during fasting compared to LGP.

questions.correct_answer: A. LGP is activated by glucagon, while MGP is activated by epinephrine.
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Liver Glycogen Phosphorylase

(Liver-specific isoform)

Muscle Glycogen Phosphorylase

(Muscle-specific isoform)

Primary Role

 Maintains blood glucose levels by breaking down glycogen during fasting Provides glucose for ATP production during muscle contraction.

Function

Converts glycogen to glucose-1-phosphate, then to glucose-6-phosphate, which is converted to free glucose by glucose-6-phosphatase and released into the bloodstream

Converts glycogen to glucose-1-phosphate, then to glucose-6-phosphate for energy production within muscle cells (muscle lacks glucose-6-phosphatase)

Hormonal Activation

 Activated by glucagon (during fasting) and epinephrine (during stress) Activated by epinephrine and AMP

Allosteric Regulation

Inhibited by glucose

Activated by AMP, inhibited by ATP and glucose-6-phosphate

Response to Fasting

Increased activity

Not significantly affected

Response to Feeding

Decreased activity

Not significantly affected

Response to Exercise

No significant change

Increased activity

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding glycogenolysis?

options.label: D
options.text: Glycogenolysis is the reverse process of glycogenesis.

questions.correct_answer: D. Glycogenolysis is the reverse process of glycogenesis.

questions.text: What is the correct order of enzymes that act in glycogenesis?
